article:
Ray Byars

Ray Byars is an American entrepreneur, businessman, and former professional racing driver. He is best known for his successful career in the racing industry, which spanned over two decades, as well as his subsequent business ventures.

#Early life

Ray Byars was born on June 11, 1952, in Charlotte, North Carolina. Growing up in a family of modest means, Byars developed a strong work ethic from an early age. His parents, both high school sweethearts, encouraged his interest in racing, which began when he was just a teenager. Byars' father, a mechanic by trade, would often take him to local racing events, where he would watch in awe as drivers sped around the track.

Byars' passion for racing only grew stronger as he entered his teenage years. He began competing in local racing events, using a car that his father had helped him build. Despite the challenges he faced, including a limited budget and lack of experience, Byars quickly made a name for himself in the racing community.

#Racing career

Byars' professional racing career began in the early 1970s, when he started competing in the NASCAR Late Model Sportsman Division. Despite facing stiff competition, Byars quickly proved himself to be a talented driver, earning several top-10 finishes and even a few wins.

In 1976, Byars made the jump to the NASCAR Grand National East Series, where he continued to impress. He earned several pole positions and even won a few races, solidifying his position as one of the top drivers in the series.

Byars' success on the track eventually caught the attention of NASCAR's top series, the Winston Cup Series. In 1979, he made his Winston Cup debut, competing in several events throughout the season. Although he didn't win any races, Byars showed promise, earning several top-20 finishes.

Over the next decade, Byars continued to compete in the Winston Cup Series, earning a reputation as a hard-nosed, aggressive driver. He competed for several different teams, including the iconic Wood Brothers Racing team. Byars' best finish in the Winston Cup Series came in 1986, when he finished 12th in the standings.

Byars retired from professional racing in the late 1990s, but his legacy lived on. He was inducted into the NASCAR Hall of Fame in 2012, a testament to his contributions to the sport.

##Racing achievements

* 1976 NASCAR Late Model Sportsman Division Champion
* 1981 NASCAR Grand National East Series Champion
* 1986 Winston Cup Series 12th place finish
* 2012 NASCAR Hall of Fame inductee

#Business career

After retiring from professional racing, Byars turned his attention to business. He had always been interested in entrepreneurship, and saw an opportunity to leverage his racing experience into a successful business career.

Byars' first business venture was a racing-themed restaurant, which he opened in his hometown of Charlotte. The restaurant, called "Byars' Pit Stop," quickly became a popular destination for racing fans and locals alike. Byars' success with the restaurant led to several other business ventures, including a chain of convenience stores and a racing-themed apparel company.

In 2005, Byars partnered with a group of investors to launch a new racing series, the American Speed Association (ASA). The series, which featured a mix of established and up-and-coming drivers, quickly gained popularity. Byars served as the series' president and CEO, using his experience and expertise to guide the series to success.

##Business achievements

* 2002 Charlotte Business Journal "40 Under 40" award winner
* 2005 ASA president and CEO
* 2010 NASCAR Entrepreneur of the Year award winner

#Awards

Throughout his career, Byars has received numerous awards and accolades. In addition to his NASCAR Hall of Fame induction, Byars has been recognized for his business achievements, including being named one of the Charlotte Business Journal's "40 Under 40" award winners in 2002.

Byars has also received several awards for his contributions to the racing community, including the NASCAR Entrepreneur of the Year award in 2010.

##Awards and accolades

* 2002 Charlotte Business Journal "40 Under 40" award winner
* 2010 NASCAR Entrepreneur of the Year award winner
* 2012 NASCAR Hall of Fame inductee

#Organizations

Byars has been involved with several organizations throughout his career, including the NASCAR Foundation and the Racing Legends Association. He has also served on the board of directors for several charitable organizations, including the Boys and Girls Clubs of America.

##Organizational involvement

* NASCAR Foundation board member
* Racing Legends Association member
* Boys and Girls Clubs of America board member

#Personal life

Byars is married to his wife, Debbie, and has two children, a son and a daughter. He currently resides in his hometown of Charlotte, North Carolina, where he remains involved in the racing community.

Byars is an avid golfer and outdoorsman, and enjoys spending time with his family and friends. Despite his many accomplishments, Byars remains humble and grounded, crediting his success to his hard work and determination.

##Personal interests

* Golf
* Outdoor activities
* Spending time with family and friends

In conclusion, Ray Byars is a highly accomplished individual who has made significant contributions to the racing industry and beyond. His dedication, perseverance, and passion have earned him a lasting legacy, and his continued involvement in the racing community ensures that his impact will be felt for generations to come.

article:
Thunivu
================

Thunivu is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language action thriller film written and directed by H. Vinoth. The film stars Ajith Kumar, Manju Warrier, and Samuthirakani in key roles. The movie follows a group of bank robbers who plan to break into a bank in Chennai, but things take a turn when they discover that the bank is a front for a large-scale money laundering operation.

Plot
-----

The story begins with a group of bank robbers, led by a mysterious figure known only as "Dark Devil" (Ajith Kumar), who plan to break into a bank in Chennai. The team, which includes experts in various fields, uses advanced technology and strategy to gain access to the bank's vault. However, things take a turn when they discover that the bank is a front for a large-scale money laundering operation run by a powerful businessman, Kanagaraj (Samuthirakani).

As the team navigates the complex web of money laundering, they realize that they have stumbled into something much bigger than they initially thought. The team must use their skills and resources to stay one step ahead of Kanagaraj and his associates, while also trying to uncover the truth behind the money laundering operation.

Cast
-----

* Ajith Kumar as Dark Devil
* Manju Warrier as Kanmani
* Samuthirakani as Kanagaraj
* Pavani Reddy as Diya
* Ajay as Sathya
* Veera as Vicky
* Ciby Bhuvana Chandran as Inspector Pradeep

Production
------------

### Development

The project was first announced in February 2022, with H. Vinoth set to write and direct the film. Ajith Kumar was confirmed to star in the lead role, marking his third collaboration with Vinoth after Nerkonda Paarvai and Valimai. The film was initially titled AK61, but was later changed to Thunivu.

### Casting

In addition to Ajith Kumar, the film features Manju Warrier, Samuthirakani, and Pavani Reddy in key roles. The cast also includes Ajay, Veera, and Ciby Bhuvana Chandran in supporting roles.

### Filming

Principal photography began in April 2022 and took place in various locations in Chennai and Hyderabad. The film's cinematography was handled by Nirav Shah, while the editing was done by Vijay Velukutty.

### Post-production

The film's post-production work began in August 2022 and was completed in November 2022. The film's soundtrack was composed by Ghibran, while the background score was composed by Anirudh Ravichander.

Music
------

The film's soundtrack features five tracks, including the title song "Chilla Chilla". The soundtrack was composed by Ghibran and was released in December 2022.

Marketing
----------

The film's marketing campaign began in November 2022, with the release of the film's first teaser. The teaser received a positive response from fans and critics alike, with many praising the film's action sequences and Ajith Kumar's performance.

Release
--------

### Theatrical

Thunivu was released in theaters on January 11, 2023, during the Pongal festival. The film received a wide release in Tamil Nadu and other parts of India, as well as in international markets.

### Pre-release business

The film's pre-release business was reported to be strong, with many distributors and exhibitors showing interest in acquiring the film's rights. The film's satellite rights were sold to Sun TV, while the digital rights were sold to Netflix.

### Distribution

The film was distributed by Red Giant Movies in Tamil Nadu and by other distributors in other parts of India. The film's international distribution was handled by Ayngaran International.

### Home media

The film's home media rights were sold to Netflix, which released the film on its platform in February 2023.

Reception
----------

Thunivu received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences, Ajith Kumar's performance, and the film's direction. The film was also a commercial success, grossing over ₹100 crore at the box office.

Notes
------

* Thunivu is Ajith Kumar's 60th film as an actor.
* The film's title, Thunivu, means "chill" or "cold" in Tamil.
* The film's soundtrack features a song titled "Chilla Chilla", which is a play on the film's title.

References
----------

External links
---------------

# Association team allocation

article:
2022 ATP Challenger Tour

The 2022 ATP Challenger Tour was the 45th season of the ATP Challenger Tour, which is the secondary level of professional tennis tournaments. The season began on 3 January 2022 and ended on 27 November 2022.

# Schedule

The schedule for the 2022 ATP Challenger Tour consisted of 184 tournaments, including 144 regular tournaments, 24 clay court tournaments, 12 hard court tournaments, 4 grass court tournaments, and 1 indoor hard court tournament.

## January

The first month of the season saw 12 tournaments take place across the globe. The first tournament of the season was the Bendigo International, held in Bendigo, Australia, which was won by Nikola Milojević. Other notable winners in January included Tomás Martín Etcheverry, who won the Buenos Aires Challenger, and Jordan Thompson, who won the Play In Challenger.

## February

February saw 15 tournaments take place, including the Challenger Rio de Janeiro, which was won by Facundo Díaz Acosta. Other notable winners in February included Nuno Borges, who won the Forlì Challenger, and Alexander Ritschard, who won the Cherbourg Challenger.

## March

March was a busy month on the ATP Challenger Tour, with 21 tournaments taking place. The month saw the return of the Phoenix Challenger, which was won by Denis Kudla. Other notable winners in March included Juan Manuel Cerúndolo, who won the Santiago Challenger, and Quentin Halys, who won the Biel Challenger.

## April

April saw 17 tournaments take place, including the Sarasota Open, which was won by Daniel Elahi Galán. Other notable winners in April included Jack Draper, who won the Sanremo Challenger, and Camilo Ugo Carabelli, who won the Split Open.

## May

May was another busy month on the ATP Challenger Tour, with 20 tournaments taking place. The month saw the return of the Heilbronn Open, which was won by Daniel Altmaier. Other notable winners in May included Pavel Kotov, who won the Ostrava Challenger, and Alexander Ritschard, who won the Trofeo Faip–Perrel–Borgogna.

## June

June saw 13 tournaments take place, including the Nottingham Open, which was won by Dan Evans. Other notable winners in June included Jason Kubler, who won the Surbiton Trophy, and Lorenzo Musetti, who won the Forlì Challenger.

## July

July saw 14 tournaments take place, including the Braunschweig Challenger, which was won by Jan-Lennard Struff. Other notable winners in July included Constant Lestienne, who won the Todi Challenger, and Gijs Brouwer, who won the Amersfoort Challenger.

## August

August saw 15 tournaments take place, including the Meerbusch Challenger, which was won by Bernabé Zapata Miralles. Other notable winners in August included Oriol Roca Batalla, who won the San Marino Open, and Facundo Díaz Acosta, who won the Banja Luka Challenger.

## September

September saw 17 tournaments take place, including the Nonthaburi Challenger, which was won by Valentin Vacherot. Other notable winners in September included Federico Coria, who won the Challenger de Buenos Aires, and Facundo Bagnis, who won the Sibiu Open.

## October

October saw 18 tournaments take place, including the Mouilleron-le-Captif Challenger, which was won by Ugo Humbert. Other notable winners in October included Hugo Grenier, who won the Saint-Tropez Challenger, and Borna Gojo, who won the Brest Challenger.

## November

November saw 10 tournaments take place, including the Bergamo Challenger, which was won by Otto Virtanen. Other notable winners in November included Vít Kopřiva, who won the Andria Challenger, and Zhizhen Zhang, who won the Hua Hin Challenger.

# Cancelled tournaments

Due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, several tournaments were cancelled or postponed during the season. These included the Chennai Open, the Koblenz Open, and the Kyiv Challenger.

# Statistical information

## Titles won by player

The following players won multiple titles during the season:

* Facundo Díaz Acosta (4 titles)
* Ugo Humbert (3 titles)
* Tomás Martín Etcheverry (3 titles)
* Daniel Altmaier (2 titles)
* Quentin Halys (2 titles)

## Titles won by nation

The following countries won multiple titles during the season:

* Argentina (14 titles)
* France (11 titles)
* United States (9 titles)
* Italy (8 titles)
* Spain (7 titles)

# Point distribution

The ATP Challenger Tour uses a points-based system to determine player rankings. The points distribution is as follows:

* Winner: 100 points
* Finalist: 60 points
* Semifinalist: 35 points
* Quarterfinalist: 18 points
* Round of 16: 9 points
* Round of 32: 4 points
* Qualifier: 2 points

article:
All In (2023)
================

All In was a professional wrestling event produced by All Elite Wrestling (AEW). It took place on August 27, 2023, at Wembley Stadium in London, England. The event was the second installment in the All In chronology, following the inaugural event held in 2018.

Production
-----------

### Background

All In was first announced on November 27, 2022, during the AEW Revolution pay-per-view event. The event was scheduled to take place at Wembley Stadium, marking the first time a professional wrestling event would be held at the iconic venue. The stadium, which has a seating capacity of over 90,000, was expected to be sold out for the event.

### Storylines

The event featured a mix of established AEW talent and newcomers, with several storylines building up to the event. One of the main storylines centered around the AEW World Heavyweight Championship, with champion MJF defending his title against a mystery opponent. Another notable storyline involved the AEW Women's World Championship, with a tournament held to determine the new champion.

Event
------

### Zero Hour

The event began with a pre-show, titled Zero Hour, which aired on AEW's social media platforms and YouTube channel. The pre-show featured three matches, including a tag team match between The Dark Order and The Butcher and The Blade.

### Preliminary matches

The main card of the event began with a match between Darby Allin and Nick Wayne. The match was a high-flying affair, with both competitors trading aerial attacks. In the end, Darby Allin emerged victorious, pinning Nick Wayne after a Coffin Drop.

The next match saw the AEW Women's World Championship qualifier tournament begin, with Britt Baker taking on Yuka Sakazaki. The match was a hard-hitting affair, with both competitors trading strikes. In the end, Britt Baker emerged victorious, advancing to the next round of the tournament.

### Main event

The main event of the evening saw MJF defend his AEW World Heavyweight Championship against a mystery opponent. The mystery opponent was revealed to be CM Punk, who made a surprise return to AEW after a lengthy absence. The match was a highly anticipated affair, with both competitors trading near-falls and submissions. In the end, CM Punk emerged victorious, pinning MJF after a GTS to win the AEW World Heavyweight Championship.

Box office
----------

All In was a major commercial success, with the event grossing over $20 million in revenue. The event was attended by over 90,000 fans, making it one of the highest-grossing professional wrestling events of all time.

Pre-show backstage altercation
-----------------------------

During the Zero Hour pre-show, a backstage altercation broke out between AEW talent The Young Bucks and The Lucha Brothers. The altercation, which was caught on camera, saw both teams trading blows and insults. The altercation was later revealed to be a worked angle, building up to a future match between the two teams.

Results
--------

### AEW Women's World Championship qualifier tournament bracket

* Britt Baker defeated Yuka Sakazaki
* Toni Storm defeated Nyla Rose
* Ruby Soho defeated Emi Sakura
* Athena defeated Penelope Ford

The winners of each match advanced to the next round of the tournament, with the eventual winner being crowned the new AEW Women's World Champion.

Notes
-----

* The event was attended by several celebrities, including actor and professional wrestler, David Arquette.
* The event was also notable for featuring a surprise appearance by WWE Hall of Famer, Ric Flair.
* The event was widely praised by fans and critics alike, with many considering it to be one of the best professional wrestling events of the year.

*None*

article:
Samnites

The Samnites were an Italic people who lived in central and southern Italy during the 1st millennium BC. They were one of the most prominent and powerful groups in the region, playing a significant role in the history of the Italian peninsula. The Samnites were known for their martial prowess, their distinctive culture, and their complex relationships with other ancient civilizations, including the Romans.

#Etymology

The origin of the name "Samnites" is unclear, but it is believed to be derived from the Oscan language, which was spoken by the Samnites and other Italic peoples. One theory is that the name comes from the Oscan word "safinim," meaning "those who live on their own land." Another theory suggests that the name is derived from the name of the Sabine goddess, Safinius.

#History

##Origins and early history

The Samnites emerged as a distinct group in the 5th century BC, in the region of Samnium, which corresponds to modern-day Abruzzo, Molise, and parts of Campania and Lazio. The Samnites were an Italic people, closely related to other groups such as the Sabines, the Latins, and the Umbri. They developed a complex society, with a system of government, economy, and culture that was distinct from other ancient civilizations.

##Samnite Wars

The Samnites were known for their martial prowess, and they played a significant role in the Samnite Wars, a series of conflicts with the Romans that lasted from 343 to 290 BC. The wars were sparked by a combination of factors, including the expansion of Roman power, the desire for control of the Italian peninsula, and the need for resources such as land and trade routes. The Samnites were eventually defeated by the Romans, but not before inflicting significant losses and damage on the Roman army.

##Later history

After the Samnite Wars, the Samnites continued to play a role in the history of the Italian peninsula. They were eventually absorbed into the Roman Empire, and many Samnites became Roman citizens. However, the Samnites maintained their cultural identity, and their legacy can still be seen in the modern-day region of Samnium.

#Society

##Economy

The Samnite economy was based on agriculture, trade, and warfare. The Samnites were skilled farmers, and they produced a variety of crops, including wheat, olives, and grapes. They also traded with other groups, including the Romans, and were known for their expertise in metalwork and craftsmanship. The Samnites were also skilled warriors, and they often engaged in raids and conquests to expand their territory and resources.

##Government

The Samnite system of government was complex and decentralized. The Samnites were organized into a series of tribes, each with its own leader and system of governance. The tribes were united under a loose confederation, with a council of elders and a system of assembly. The Samnites also had a system of laws and justice, with a focus on individual rights and freedoms.

##Military

The Samnite military was known for its discipline, organization, and martial prowess. The Samnites were skilled warriors, and they developed a distinctive style of warfare that emphasized speed, agility, and surprise. The Samnites were also known for their expertise in siege warfare, and they developed a range of technologies, including catapults and ballistae.

###Armor

The Samnites wore a distinctive type of armor, known as the "scutum." The scutum was a large, rectangular shield made of wood or metal, with a curved surface and a long handle. The Samnites also wore helmets, greaves, and breastplates, and carried swords and spears.

###Weaponry

The Samnites were skilled craftsmen, and they developed a range of distinctive weapons, including the "gladius," a short, curved sword, and the "pilum," a heavy javelin with a long handle. The Samnites also used catapults and ballistae, which were powered by torsion or tension.

#Culture

##Religion

The Samnite religion was complex and polytheistic, with a focus on a range of gods and goddesses, including Jupiter, Mars, and Venus. The Samnites also believed in a range of supernatural beings, including spirits and ancestors. The Samnites practiced a range of rituals and ceremonies, including sacrifices, festivals, and divination.

##Gender roles

The Samnites had a complex system of gender roles, with men and women playing different roles in society. Men were expected to be warriors and leaders, while women were expected to be wives and mothers. However, women also played a significant role in Samnite society, and were often involved in trade, agriculture, and other economic activities.

##Art

Tropical Storm Alex (2022)

Tropical Storm Alex was a tropical cyclone that formed in the Atlantic Ocean in June 2022. The storm caused significant disruptions and damage in several countries in the Caribbean and the southeastern United States. This article provides an overview of the storm's meteorological history, its impact on various regions, and related information.

#Meteorological history

Tropical Storm Alex formed on June 2, 2022, from a tropical wave that had been moving westward across the Atlantic Ocean. At the time of its formation, the storm was located approximately 1,000 miles (1,609 km) east-southeast of the Lesser Antilles. The storm system was characterized by a broad area of low pressure and a large mass of thunderstorms.

Over the next few days, Alex moved west-northwestward, gradually strengthening as it did so. By June 4, the storm had developed a well-defined center and was producing sustained winds of up to 60 miles per hour (97 km/h). At this point, the National Hurricane Center (NHC) classified Alex as a tropical storm.

As Alex continued to move west-northwestward, it encountered a belt of strong upper-level winds that caused the storm to weaken. By June 6, Alex had degenerated into a tropical wave, with the NHC discontinuing advisories on the system.

However, Alex's remnants continued to move westward, eventually reaching the southeastern United States. On June 8, the NHC re-initiated advisories on Alex, as the storm had re-developed a closed circulation and was producing sustained winds of up to 40 miles per hour (64 km/h).

Over the next few days, Alex moved northward, impacting several states in the southeastern United States. The storm eventually dissipated on June 12, as it moved inland over the Mid-Atlantic region.

#Preparations and impact

Tropical Storm Alex caused significant disruptions and damage in several countries in the Caribbean and the southeastern United States.

##Cuba

On June 3, the Cuban government issued a tropical storm warning for the provinces of Camagüey, Las Tunas, Holguín, and Guantanamo. The warning was later extended to include the provinces of Santiago de Cuba and Granma.

As Alex approached the island, strong winds and heavy rainfall caused significant disruptions. The storm made landfall on June 4, bringing with it sustained winds of up to 60 miles per hour (97 km/h). The storm caused widespread power outages, with over 100,000 households left without electricity.

The Cuban government reported that the storm had caused significant damage to the country's agricultural sector, with over 10,000 hectares of crops affected. The storm also caused significant disruptions to the country's transportation network, with several roads and highways closed due to flooding.

##Florida

On June 5, the National Weather Service issued a tropical storm watch for the state of Florida, as Alex was forecast to bring strong winds and heavy rainfall to the region. The watch was later upgraded to a tropical storm warning, as the storm's forecast track shifted westward.

As Alex approached the state, strong winds and heavy rainfall caused significant disruptions. The storm made landfall on June 6, bringing with it sustained winds of up to 40 miles per hour (64 km/h). The storm caused widespread power outages, with over 50,000 households left without electricity.

The Florida Department of Transportation reported that the storm had caused significant disruptions to the state's transportation network, with several roads and highways closed due to flooding. The storm also caused significant damage to the state's agricultural sector, with over 5,000 hectares of crops affected.

##The Bahamas

On June 5, the Bahamian government issued a tropical storm warning for the islands of Grand Bahama and the Abacos. The warning was later extended to include the islands of Andros and Berry.

As Alex approached the islands, strong winds and heavy rainfall caused significant disruptions. The storm made landfall on June 6, bringing with it sustained winds of up to 40 miles per hour (64 km/h). The storm caused widespread power outages, with over 10,000 households left without electricity.

The Bahamian government reported that the storm had caused significant damage to the country's infrastructure, with over 100 homes damaged or destroyed. The storm also caused significant disruptions to the country's transportation network, with several roads and highways closed due to flooding.

article:
Testate Succession in South African Law

Testate succession in South African law refers to the process by which a deceased person's estate is distributed according to their will. The will is a document that outlines the testator's wishes regarding the distribution of their assets, and it must be executed in accordance with the formalities set out in the law. This article provides an overview of the key aspects of testate succession in South African law, including the freedom of testation, testamentary capacity, formalities for execution of a will, condonation, invalid wills, and the effect of wills.

# Freedom of Testation

The freedom of testation is the principle that a testator has the right to dispose of their assets as they see fit, subject to certain limitations. This principle is enshrined in the common law and is also reflected in various statutes.

## Limitations

There are several limitations on the freedom of testation, including:

### Illegal Dispositions and Those Against Public Policy

A testator cannot make dispositions that are illegal or against public policy. For example, a testator cannot leave property to a person who is not capable of inheriting it, such as a minor or a person who is not a citizen of South Africa.

### Subdivision of Agricultural Land

The Subdivision of Agricultural Land Act, 1970, prohibits the subdivision of agricultural land into smaller portions, except in certain circumstances.

### Subdivision of Mineral Rights

The Mineral and Petroleum Resources Development Act, 2002, regulates the subdivision of mineral rights and prohibits the subdivision of mineral rights into smaller portions, except in certain circumstances.

### Fideicommissum Multiplex

A fideicommissum multiplex is a disposition where a testator leaves property to one person for life, and then to another person or persons after the death of the first person. This type of disposition is subject to certain restrictions and requirements.

### Maintenance of Surviving Spouse

The Maintenance of Surviving Spouses Act, 1990, requires a testator to make provision for the maintenance of their surviving spouse, regardless of whether the spouse is a beneficiary under the will.

### Maintenance and Education of Minor Children

The Maintenance Act, 1998, requires a testator to make provision for the maintenance and education of their minor children.

### Pension Funds

The Pension Funds Act, 1956, regulates the distribution of pension funds and prohibits the distribution of pension funds to beneficiaries who are not entitled to receive them.

## Delegation

A testator can delegate their power to dispose of their assets to another person, such as an executor or trustee. However, this delegation must be made in accordance with the formalities set out in the law.

## Customary Law

Customary law plays an important role in the law of succession in South Africa, particularly in relation to the distribution of assets in accordance with customary law. However, customary law is subject to the Constitution and the Bill of Rights, and any customary law that is inconsistent with the Constitution or the Bill of Rights is invalid.

# Testamentary Capacity

Testamentary capacity refers to the mental ability of a testator to make a valid will. A testator must have the necessary mental ability to understand the nature and extent of their assets, as well as the nature and extent of the dispositions they are making.

## Mental Ability of the Testator

A testator must have the necessary mental ability to make a valid will. This includes the ability to understand the nature and extent of their assets, as well as the nature and extent of the dispositions they are making.

## Undue Influence on the Testator

A testator must not be subject to undue influence when making their will. Undue influence occurs when a person uses coercion or manipulation to influence the testator's decisions.

# Capacity to Witness a Will

A person who witnesses a will must have the necessary capacity to do so. This includes the ability to understand the nature and extent of the dispositions being made, as well as the ability to sign the will in the presence of the testator.

# Formalities for Execution of a Will

A will must be executed in accordance with the formalities set out in the law. This includes the requirement that the will be in writing, signed by the testator, and witnessed by two or more competent witnesses.

## Requirements for a Testamentary Disposition

A testamentary disposition must be made in accordance with the formalities set out in the law. This includes the requirement that the disposition be in writing, signed by the testator, and witnessed by two or more competent witnesses.

## Methods of Executing a Valid Will

There are several methods of executing a valid will, including:

### Signing and Signature

A will must be signed by the testator in the presence of two or more competent witnesses. The signature must be made in such a way that it is clear that the testator intended to sign the will.

### Certificate

A certificate is a document that is attached to the will and signed by the witnesses. The certificate confirms that the will was signed by the testator in the presence of the witnesses.

### Witnesses

A will must be witnessed by two or more competent witnesses. The witnesses must sign the will in the presence of the testator and must also sign the certificate.

# Condonation

Condonation is the process by which a court condones a will that does not comply with the formalities set out in the law. Condonation is only possible in certain circumstances, such as where the testator intended to make a valid will but was prevented from doing so due to circumstances beyond their control.

# Invalid Wills

An invalid will is a will that does not comply with the formalities set out in the law. An invalid will can be challenged by any person who has an interest in the estate.

## Revocation

A will can be revoked by the testator at any time. Revocation can be done by executing a new will, or by physically destroying the existing will.

### Right of Revocation

A testator has the right to revoke their will at any time. This right is absolute and cannot be limited by any person or entity.

### Manner

A will can be revoked in several ways, including:

#### Later Will or Codicil

A will can be revoked by executing a later will or codicil. The later will or codicil must be executed in accordance with the formalities set out in the law.

#### Physical or Symbolic Destruction

A will can be revoked by physically destroying the will, or by symbolically destroying the will, such as by tearing it up or burning it.

#### Ademption

A will can be revoked by ademption, which occurs when a specific gift is revoked due to the testator's subsequent actions, such as selling the gifted property.

#### Other Means of Revocation

A will can be revoked by other means, such as by a court order or by the testator's subsequent marriage or divorce.

#### Divorce or Annulment of Marriage

A will can be revoked by the testator's subsequent divorce or annulment of marriage. This is because the testator's spouse is no longer entitled to inherit under the will.

### Exceptions to the General Rule that a Will Can Be Revoked

There are several exceptions to the general rule that a will can be revoked, including:

### Revival of a Revoked Will

A revoked will can be revived by the testator's subsequent actions, such as by executing a new will that revives the revoked will.

## Alteration or Variation

A will can be altered or varied by the testator at any time. Alteration or variation can be done by executing a new will or by executing a codicil.

### Amendment by Testator

A will can be amended by the testator at any time. Amendment can be done by executing a new will or by executing a codicil.

### Rectification by Court

A will can be rectified by a court if it contains errors or ambiguities. Rectification can be done by a court order.

### Alteration or Variation by the Court

A will can be altered or varied by a court if it is necessary to carry out the testator's intentions. Alteration or variation can be done by a court order.

## Incorporation by Reference

A will can incorporate other documents by reference. Incorporation by reference can be done by including a reference to the other document in the will.

# Obsolete and Provincial Wills

An obsolete will is a will that was executed before the current legislation came into effect. A provincial will is a will that was executed in a province other than the province in which the testator died.

# Joint or Mutual Wills

A joint will is a will that is executed by two or more people. A mutual will is a will that is executed by two or more people who are married to each other.

# Probate of Wills

Probate is the process by which a will is proved to be valid. Probate is necessary before the estate can be distributed.

## Lost Wills

A lost will is a will that cannot be found. A lost will can be proved by other evidence, such as a copy of the will or a witness's testimony.

# Content of Wills

A will must contain certain information, including:

## Inheritance and Legacy

A will must contain a description of the property that is being left to each beneficiary. The property can be left as an inheritance or as a legacy.

## Prior and Legal Rights

A will must contain a description of the prior and legal rights of each beneficiary. Prior and legal rights include the right to inherit certain property, such as a spouse's share of the estate.

## Vested, Conditional and Future Interests

A will can contain vested, conditional and future interests. Vested interests are interests that are currently possessed by the beneficiary. Conditional interests are interests that are dependent on certain conditions being met. Future interests are interests that will be possessed by the beneficiary in the future.

## Vested Interests

Vested interests are interests that are currently possessed by the beneficiary. Vested interests can be created by a will or by a deed.

## Conditional Interests

Conditional interests are interests that are dependent on certain conditions being met. Conditional interests can be created by a will or by a deed.

### Future Interests

Future interests are interests that will be possessed by the beneficiary in the future. Future interests can be created by a will or by a deed.

### Valid and Invalid Conditions

Conditions can be valid or invalid. Valid conditions are conditions that are lawful and reasonable. Invalid conditions are conditions that are unlawful or unreasonable.

## Nudum Praeceptum

A nudum praeceptum is a direction or instruction that is included in a will. A nudum praeceptum can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

## Estate Massing

Estate massing is the process of combining all of the assets of an estate into a single pool. Estate massing can be used to simplify the administration of an estate.

## Customary Law

Customary law plays an important role in the law of succession in South Africa. Customary law can be used to determine the distribution of assets in an estate.

## Testamentary Devices

Testamentary devices are mechanisms that can be used to create trusts or to impose conditions on beneficiaries. Testamentary devices include usufructs, substitutions and fideicommissa.

### Usufruct

A usufruct is a right to use and enjoy property that is owned by someone else. A usufruct can be created by a will or by a deed.

### Substitution

A substitution is a mechanism that allows a beneficiary to receive property instead of another beneficiary. A substitution can be created by a will or by a deed.

#### Direct Substitution

A direct substitution is a substitution that is made directly from one beneficiary to another. A direct substitution can be created by a will or by a deed.

#### Fideicommissary Substitution

A fideicommissary substitution is a substitution that is made through a fideicommissum. A fideicommissary substitution can be created by a will or by a deed.

### Difference between Usufruct and Fideicommissum

A usufruct and a fideicommissum are both mechanisms that can be used to create trusts or to impose conditions on beneficiaries. However, a usufruct is a right to use and enjoy property, while a fideicommissum is a mechanism that allows a beneficiary to receive property instead of another beneficiary.

### Fideicommissum Residui

A fideicommissum residui is a fideicommissum that is created over the residue of an estate. A fideicommissum residui can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Fideicommissum Purum

A fideicommissum purum is a fideicommissum that is not subject to any conditions. A fideicommissum purum can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Trust

A trust is a mechanism that allows a person to manage property on behalf of another person. A trust can be created by a will or by a deed.

## Bequests Subject to a Modus

A bequest can be subject to a modus, which is a condition or restriction that is imposed on the beneficiary. A modus can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

## Interpretation of Some Common Dispositions in Wills

The interpretation of dispositions in wills can be complex and nuanced. Some common dispositions that require interpretation include:

### Presumption against Fideicommissa

There is a presumption against fideicommissa, which means that a court will not interpret a disposition as a fideicommissum unless it is clear that the testator intended to create a fideicommissum.

### Si Sine Liberis Decesserit Clause

A si sine liberis decesserit clause is a clause that is included in a will to provide for the distribution of property in the event that the beneficiary dies without leaving any children. A si sine liberis decesserit clause can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

## Implied Fideicommissa

An implied fideicommissum is a fideicommissum that is not explicitly stated in a will, but can be implied from the language and circumstances of the will. An implied fideicommissum can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Fideicommissum Subject to a Si Sine Liberis Condition

A fideicommissum that is subject to a si sine liberis condition is a fideicommissum that is created over property that will only pass to the beneficiary if the beneficiary does not have any children. A fideicommissum subject to a si sine liberis condition can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Prohibitions against Alienation

A prohibition against alienation is a restriction that is imposed on a beneficiary to prevent them from selling or transferring property. A prohibition against alienation can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

## Statutory Aids to Interpretation

There are several statutory aids to interpretation that can be used to interpret dispositions in wills. These statutory aids include the Wills Act, the Administration of Estates Act and the Trust Property Control Act.

## Combinations of Various Interests

It is possible to combine various interests in a will, such as a usufruct and a fideicommissum. The combination of various interests can be used to create a complex estate plan that meets the needs of the testator and their beneficiaries.

### Fideicommissum upon Fideicommissum

A fideicommissum upon a fideicommissum is a fideicommissum that is created over property that is already subject to a fideicommissum. A fideicommissum upon a fideicommissum can be used to create a complex estate plan that meets the needs of the testator and their beneficiaries.

### Compendiosa Substitutio

A compendiosa substitutio is a substitution that is made over property that is already subject to a fideicommissum. A compendiosa substitutio can be used to create a complex estate plan that meets the needs of the testator and their beneficiaries.

### Ownership Subject to a Usufruct with a Direct Substitution as to the Usufruct at the Testator’s Death

Ownership subject to a usufruct with a direct substitution as to the usufruct at the testator’s death is a complex estate plan that combines a usufruct with a direct substitution. This type of estate plan can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Ownership Subject to a Usufruct as to which there is a Fideicommissary Substitution

Ownership subject to a usufruct as to which there is a fideicommissary substitution is a complex estate plan that combines a usufruct with a fideicommissary substitution. This type of estate plan can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Ownership Subject to a Usufruct with a Direct Substitution as to the Ownership at the Testator’s Death

Ownership subject to a usufruct with a direct substitution as to the ownership at the testator’s death is a complex estate plan that combines a usufruct with a direct substitution. This type of estate plan can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Ownership Subject to a Usufruct with a Direct Substitution as to the Ownership at the Death of the Usufructuary

Ownership subject to a usufruct with a direct substitution as to the ownership at the death of the usufructuary is a complex estate plan that combines a usufruct with a direct substitution. This type of estate plan can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

### Fideicommissum in which one Fideicommissary is Directly Substituted for Another

A fideicommissum in which one fideicommissary is directly substituted for another is a complex estate plan that combines a fideicommissum with a direct substitution. This type of estate plan can be used to create a trust or to impose a condition on a beneficiary.

# Effect of Wills

A will has several effects on the estate of the testator, including:

## Rights of Heirs

The rights of heirs are affected by a will, as the will can create new rights or alter existing rights.

## Rights of Legatees

The rights of legatees are affected by a will, as the will can create new rights or alter existing rights.

### Abatement of Legacies

Abatement of legacies occurs when the assets of the estate are insufficient to pay all of the legacies. In this case, the legacies are abated, or reduced, in proportion to the value of the assets.

## Rights of Fiduciaries and Fideicommissaries

The rights of fiduciaries and fideicommissaries are affected by a will, as the will can create new rights or alter existing rights.

## Ius Accrescendi

Ius accrescendi is the right of a beneficiary to receive a larger share of the estate if another beneficiary does not survive the testator.

### Express Provision Concerning Accrual

An express provision concerning accrual is a provision in a will that provides for the accrual of a beneficiary’s share of the estate.

Anna Paulina Luna
================

Anna Paulina Luna is an American politician and former U.S. Air Force veteran who has served as the U.S. Representative for Florida's 13th congressional district since 2023. A member of the Republican Party, Luna represents a district that includes parts of St. Petersburg and Clearwater.

Family and early life
--------------------

Luna was born on May 6, 1989, in Irvine, California. Her parents, George and Elizabeth, were both of Mexican descent, and her father served in the U.S. Marine Corps. Luna has stated that she grew up in a low-income household and had to work multiple jobs to support her family. She has also spoken publicly about experiencing poverty and food insecurity during her childhood.

Luna's family moved frequently during her childhood, eventually settling in Texas. She attended a magnet school for science and technology in the Houston area, where she excelled academically and developed an interest in mathematics and science.

Early career and education
-------------------------

After graduating from high school, Luna enlisted in the U.S. Air Force, where she served for five years as a cryptologic language analyst. During her time in the military, Luna deployed to the Middle East and was stationed in various locations around the world.

After leaving the Air Force, Luna attended the University of West Florida, where she earned a degree in biology. She later earned a master's degree in public health from the same institution.

U.S. House of Representatives
-----------------------------

### Elections

#### 2020

Luna first ran for Congress in 2020, seeking the Republican nomination for Florida's 13th congressional district. She defeated several opponents in the primary, including a well-funded candidate backed by the National Republican Congressional Committee. Luna went on to lose the general election to Democratic incumbent Charlie Crist.

#### 2022

Luna ran for Congress again in 2022, this time winning the Republican primary with over 40% of the vote. In the general election, she faced off against Democratic nominee Eric Lynn and won by a margin of just over 4%.

### Tenure

Luna took office on January 3, 2023, becoming the first Republican to represent Florida's 13th congressional district in over a decade. She is currently serving on the House Committee on Veterans' Affairs and the House Committee on Small Business.

### Caucus membership(s)

Luna is a member of the House Freedom Caucus, a group of conservative Republicans who advocate for limited government and fiscal responsibility.

### Committee assignments

* House Committee on Veterans' Affairs
* House Committee on Small Business

Political positions
------------------

### 2020 presidential election

Luna was a vocal supporter of Donald Trump's presidential campaign in 2020, and has expressed admiration for the former president's policies and leadership style.

### Abortion

Luna has described herself as "pro-life" and has expressed opposition to abortion in most circumstances. She has also stated that she would support legislation to restrict access to abortion services.

### Economy

Luna has advocated for tax cuts and reduced government spending as a means of stimulating economic growth. She has also expressed support for the oil and gas industry, which is a significant employer in her district.

### Education

Luna has expressed support for school choice and charter schools, and has advocated for increased funding for vocational training programs.

### Gun control

Luna has stated that she is a strong supporter of the Second Amendment and has expressed opposition to most forms of gun control. She has also advocated for concealed carry reciprocity and has expressed support for the National Rifle Association.

### Twitter

Luna is active on social media, particularly Twitter, where she has gained a significant following for her outspoken views on politics and culture.

### Foreign policy

Luna has expressed support for a strong national defense and has advocated for increased funding for the military. She has also expressed skepticism of international institutions and has advocated for a more isolationist foreign policy.

Disputed biographical claims
-----------------------------

### Religious and ethnic background

Luna has stated that she is of Mexican descent and was raised Catholic, but some have questioned the accuracy of these claims. Luna has responded by releasing a statement from her parents confirming her ethnic and religious background.

### Difficult childhood

Luna has spoken publicly about experiencing poverty and food insecurity during her childhood, but some have questioned the accuracy of these claims. Luna has responded by releasing financial records and other documentation to support her account.

### Father's incarceration

Luna has stated that her father was incarcerated for a period of time during her childhood, but some have questioned the accuracy of this claim. Luna has responded by releasing documentation from the relevant authorities to support her account.

### Home break-in

Luna has stated that her family's home was broken into during her childhood, but some have questioned the accuracy of this claim. Luna has responded by releasing a statement from a family member confirming the incident.

### Conflict with uncle

Luna has stated that she had a difficult relationship with an uncle who abused her as a child, but some have questioned the accuracy of this claim. Luna has responded by releasing a statement from a family member confirming the abuse.

Personal life

Murdaugh Family

The Murdaugh family is a prominent family in the Lowcountry region of South Carolina, particularly in the 14th Circuit Solicitor's Office, where they have held the position of solicitor for over 80 years. The family is also known for their law firm, Peters Murdaugh Parker Eltzroth & Detrick (PMPED), which has been involved in various high-profile cases.

# 14th District

The 14th Circuit Solicitor's Office, also known as the 14th Judicial Circuit, is a prosecutorial district that serves five counties in the Lowcountry region of South Carolina, including Allendale, Beaufort, Colleton, Hampton, and Jasper. The office is responsible for prosecuting crimes in these counties, and the solicitor is the chief prosecutor. The Murdaugh family has held the position of solicitor for over 80 years, with Randolph Murdaugh Sr. serving as the first family member to hold the position.

# Family Law Firm

Peters Murdaugh Parker Eltzroth & Detrick (PMPED) is a law firm based in Hampton, South Carolina, that was founded by Randolph Murdaugh Sr. and his brother, Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. The firm specializes in personal injury and wrongful death cases, and has been involved in various high-profile cases over the years. The firm has also been involved in various controversies, including allegations of embezzlement and assisted suicide fraud.

# Murdaugh Hunting Estate

The Murdaugh family owns a hunting estate in Islandton, South Carolina, known as Moselle. The estate has been the site of various hunting trips and social events over the years, and has also been the subject of controversy, including allegations of poaching and animal cruelty.

# Notable Members

## Randolph Murdaugh Sr.

Randolph Murdaugh Sr. was the founder of the Murdaugh family's law firm, PMPED, and served as the solicitor for the 14th Judicial Circuit from 1920 until his death in 1940. He was a prominent figure in the Lowcountry region of South Carolina and was known for his involvement in various charitable organizations.

## Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr.

Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. was the brother of Randolph Murdaugh Sr. and co-founder of PMPED. He served as the solicitor for the 14th Judicial Circuit from 1940 until his retirement in 1986. He was also a prominent figure in the Lowcountry region of South Carolina and was known for his involvement in various charitable organizations.

## Randolph Murdaugh III

Randolph Murdaugh III is the son of Randolph "Buster" Murdaugh Jr. and served as the solicitor for the 14th Judicial Circuit from 1986 until his retirement in 2006. He was also a partner in the law firm PMPED and was involved in various high-profile cases over the years.

## Alex Murdaugh

Alex Murdaugh is the son of Randolph Murdaugh III and a partner in the law firm PMPED. He has been involved in various high-profile cases over the years, including the murder of his wife and son in 2021.

## Maggie Murdaugh

Maggie Murdaugh was the wife of Alex Murdaugh and the mother of their two sons, Buster and Paul. She was a member of the prominent Murdaugh family and was known for her involvement in various charitable organizations.

## Buster Murdaugh

Buster Murdaugh is the son of Alex and Maggie Murdaugh and the grandson of Randolph Murdaugh III. He is a student at the University of South Carolina and has been involved in various controversies over the years, including allegations of embezzlement and assisted suicide fraud.

## Paul Murdaugh

Paul Murdaugh was the son of Alex and Maggie Murdaugh and the grandson of Randolph Murdaugh III. He was a student at the University of South Carolina and was known for his involvement in various charitable organizations. He was murdered in 2021, along with his mother, Maggie.

# Alex Murdaugh Murders and Other Legal Issues

Alex Murdaugh has been involved in various legal issues over the years, including allegations of embezzlement, assisted suicide fraud, and murder.

## Ongoing Investigations and Legal Actions

### Murder of Stephen Smith

Stephen Smith was a 19-year-old man who was found dead on the side of the road in Hampton County, South Carolina, in 2015. Alex Murdaugh's son, Buster, was a classmate of Smith's and had been involved in a car accident with him just days before his death. The case remains unsolved, but investigators have reopened it in light of new evidence.

### Death of Gloria Satterfield

Gloria Satterfield was a 57-year-old housekeeper who worked for the Murdaugh family. She died in 2018 after falling down the stairs at the family's home. Alex Murdaugh's insurance company paid out over $500,000 in life insurance benefits, but Satterfield's family claims that they never received the money.

Mallory Beach was a 19-year-old woman who died in a boating accident in 2019. Alex Murdaugh's son, Paul, was driving the boat at the time of the accident and was charged with felony boating under the influence. The case remains ongoing.

### Assisted Suicide Fraud

Alex Murdaugh has been accused of assisted suicide fraud after his father, Randolph Murdaugh III, died in 2021. Investigators claim that Murdaugh helped his father to die and then collected life insurance benefits.

Alex Murdaugh has been ordered to surrender his firearms and other dangerous items as part of an ongoing investigation into his involvement in the murder of his wife and son.

article:
Harry Belafonte
================

Harold George Bellanfanti Jr., known professionally as Harry Belafonte, is a Jamaican-American singer, songwriter, actor, and social activist. One of the most successful Jamaican musicians in history, Belafonte is best known for his iconic calypso-influenced music, including the hit songs "Day-O (The Banana Boat Song)" and "Jamaica Farewell". With a career spanning over seven decades, Belafonte has been a prominent figure in the entertainment industry, using his platform to advocate for civil rights, social justice, and humanitarian causes.

Early Life
-----------

Born on March 1, 1927, in Harlem, New York, Belafonte was the son of Melvine Love and Harold George Bellanfanti, a chef and sailor. His mother was of Jamaican and Martinican ancestry, and his father was of French and English descent. When Belafonte was three years old, his family moved to Jamaica, where he spent much of his childhood. He returned to New York City at the age of 13 and attended George Washington High School.

Musical Career
--------------

### Early Years (1949–1955)

Belafonte began his music career in the late 1940s, performing in jazz clubs and folk venues in New York City. He was influenced by traditional Caribbean music, American jazz, and folk music. In 1949, he joined the American Negro Theatre, where he met Sidney Poitier, with whom he would later collaborate on film projects. Belafonte's early recordings were released on the Jubilee Records label, but it was his 1952 single "They Didn't Believe Me" that brought him his first taste of success.

### Rise to Fame (1956–1958)

In 1956, Belafonte released his breakthrough album, "Calypso", which became the first album to sell over one million copies in the United States. The album's success was fueled by the hit single "Day-O (The Banana Boat Song)", which became a signature tune for Belafonte. He continued to release successful albums throughout the late 1950s, including "Belafonte Sings of the Caribbean" and "Belafonte".

### Middle Career (1959–1970)

During the 1960s, Belafonte expanded his musical repertoire, incorporating more traditional Caribbean and African music into his recordings. He released several successful albums, including "My Lord What a Mornin'" and "Homeward Bound". In 1961, he was awarded a Grammy Award for Best Folk Performance for his album "Swing Dat Hammer".

### Later Recordings and Subsequent Activities (1971–2017)

In the 1970s and 1980s, Belafonte continued to release music, albeit at a slower pace. He released several albums, including "Play Me" and "Turn the World Around". In the 1990s and 2000s, he released several compilation albums and live recordings. In 2017, Belafonte released his final studio album, "When Colors Come Together".

Film Career
------------

### Early Film Career (1953–1956)

Belafonte made his film debut in 1953 with a supporting role in the film "Bright Road". He went on to appear in several films throughout the 1950s, including "Carmen Jones" and "Island in the Sun".

### Rise as an Actor (1957–1959)

In 1957, Belafonte starred in the film "Island in the Sun", alongside Joan Fontaine and Dorothy Dandridge. The film was a commercial success, and Belafonte's performance earned him critical acclaim. He went on to appear in several more films throughout the late 1950s, including "The St. Louis Blues" and "Odds Against Tomorrow".

### Later Film and Theatre Involvement (1960–2018)

In the 1960s and 1970s, Belafonte continued to appear in films, including "The Angel Levine" and "Uptown Saturday Night". He also began to work in theatre, appearing in several Off-Broadway productions. In the 1980s and 1990s, Belafonte appeared in several television films and documentaries. In 2018, he appeared in the documentary film "Harry Belafonte: Sing Your Song".

Political Activism
------------------

### Involvement in the Civil Rights Movement

Belafonte was an early supporter of the Civil Rights Movement, and he worked closely with Martin Luther King Jr. throughout the 1950s and 1960s. He participated in several marches and protests, including the 1963 March on Washington. Belafonte also provided financial support to the movement, helping to fund several organizations, including the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.

### Involvement in the Kennedy Campaign

In 1960, Belafonte supported John F. Kennedy's presidential campaign, and he performed at several campaign events. After Kennedy's election, Belafonte was a frequent visitor to the White House, and he worked closely with the Kennedy administration on several issues.

### The Baldwin-Kennedy Meeting

In 1963, Belafonte helped to arrange a meeting between Kennedy and a group of African American artists and intellectuals, including James Baldwin and Lena Horne. The meeting was an attempt to address the growing tensions between the Kennedy administration and the Civil Rights Movement.

### Obama Administration

In 2008, Belafonte supported Barack Obama's presidential campaign, and he performed at several campaign events. After Obama's election, Belafonte was a frequent visitor to the White House, and he worked closely with the Obama administration on several issues.

### Support for Bernie Sanders

In 2016, Belafonte supported Bernie Sanders' presidential campaign, and he performed at several campaign events. After Sanders' loss, Belafonte continued to work with the Sanders Institute, a non-profit organization founded by Sanders and his wife, Jane.

### The Sanders Institute

In 2017, Belafonte became a member of the board of directors of the Sanders Institute, a non-profit organization founded by Bernie Sanders and his wife, Jane. The institute is dedicated to promoting progressive policies and social justice.

Humanitarian Activism
---------------------

### HIV/AIDS Crisis

In the 1980s, Belafonte became involved in the fight against HIV/AIDS, and he worked closely with several organizations, including the American Foundation for AIDS Research. He also performed at several benefit concerts, including the 1985 "Live Aid" concert.

### Prostate Cancer Awareness

In the 1990s, Belafonte became involved in prostate cancer awareness, and he worked closely with several organizations, including the Prostate Cancer Foundation. He also performed at several benefit concerts, including the 1999 " prostate Cancer Benefit" concert.

### Work with UNICEF

In the 1990s and 2000s, Belafonte worked closely with UNICEF, and he became a goodwill ambassador for the organization. He participated in several UNICEF campaigns, including the "UNICEF Tap Project", which aimed to provide clean drinking water to children around the world.

### Various Activist Work

Throughout his career, Belafonte has been involved in several other activist causes, including the anti-apartheid movement and the environmental movement. He has also worked closely with several organizations, including the NAACP and the ACLU.

### New York City Pride Parade

In 2019, Belafonte participated in the New York City Pride Parade, and he was honored with the "Pride Award" for his work in promoting LGBTQ+ rights.

Belafonte and Foreign Policy
-----------------------------

### Opposition to the George W. Bush Administration

In 2003, Belafonte publicly opposed the George W. Bush administration's invasion of Iraq, and he participated in several anti-war protests. He also criticized the administration's handling of Hurricane Katrina, and he worked closely with several organizations to provide aid to the affected areas.

Business Career
----------------

In addition to his music and film career, Belafonte has also been involved in several business ventures. In the 1960s, he founded the Belafonte Enterprises production company, which produced several films and television shows. He has also invested in several other businesses, including real estate and restaurants.

Personal Life, Health, and Death
---------------------------------

Belafonte has been married three times, and he has four children. He has been open about his struggles with prostate cancer and heart disease, and he has undergone several surgeries. In 2020, Belafonte announced that he had been diagnosed with dementia, and he has since become an advocate for dementia awareness.

article:
FIFA World Cup Records and Statistics

The FIFA World Cup is an international soccer tournament held every four years, featuring national teams from all over the world. The tournament has a rich history, and over the years, numerous records and statistics have been accumulated. This article presents a comprehensive collection of FIFA World Cup records and statistics, covering various aspects of the tournament, including team and player performances, goalscoring, coaching, and refereeing.

**List of tournaments**

The FIFA World Cup has been held 22 times since its inception in 1930. The following is a list of all FIFA World Cup tournaments, including the host country, the winner, and the runner-up:

* 1930: Uruguay (winner), Argentina (runner-up)
* 1934: Italy (winner), Czechoslovakia (runner-up)
* 1938: France (winner), Italy (runner-up)
* 1950: Brazil (winner), Uruguay (runner-up)
* 1954: Switzerland (winner), Hungary (runner-up)
* 1958: Sweden (winner), Brazil (runner-up)
* 1962: Chile (winner), Czechoslovakia (runner-up)
* 1966: England (winner), West Germany (runner-up)
* 1970: Mexico (winner), Brazil (runner-up)
* 1974: West Germany (winner), Netherlands (runner-up)
* 1978: Argentina (winner), Netherlands (runner-up)

* 1986: Mexico (winner), Argentina (runner-up)

* 2018: Russia (winner), France (runner-up)

article:
The Bloodline

The Bloodline is a professional wrestling stable in WWE, currently performing on the SmackDown brand. The group is led by Solo Sikoa and consists of members from the Anoa'i wrestling dynasty, including The Usos, Roman Reigns, and others. The stable is known for their dominant performances and championships won in WWE.

Background
----------

The Anoa'i family has a long history in professional wrestling, with many members achieving great success in the industry. The Usos, Roman Reigns, and other members of The Bloodline are part of this wrestling dynasty. The stable's formation was a natural progression of the family's involvement in professional wrestling.

History
-------

### The Usos' feud with The Shield (2013–2014)

The Usos, consisting of Jimmy and Jey Uso, began their feud with The Shield, a stable consisting of Dean Ambrose, Seth Rollins, and Roman Reigns, in 2013. The two teams had a series of matches, with The Usos eventually emerging as the top contenders for the WWE Tag Team Championship. Although they did not win the titles, their feud with The Shield helped establish them as a top team in WWE.

### Occasional team-ups (2015–2020)

Over the next several years, The Usos and Roman Reigns would occasionally team up, often to take on common foes. These team-ups were sporadic, but they helped lay the groundwork for the eventual formation of The Bloodline.

### Roman Reigns' leadership (2020–2024)

#### Official Formation of The Bloodline (2020–2021)

In 2020, Roman Reigns, now established as a top singles competitor, began to recruit members for a new stable. He was joined by The Usos, who had recently turned heel, and Paul Heyman, a longtime friend and ally. The group, now known as The Bloodline, quickly established themselves as a dominant force in WWE.

#### All champions, rivalry with The New Day (2021–2022)

In 2021, The Bloodline achieved a major milestone, with all members holding championships simultaneously. Roman Reigns was the Universal Champion, while The Usos held the SmackDown Tag Team Championship. The group's dominance was put to the test by The New Day, a long-established stable consisting of Kofi Kingston, Xavier Woods, and Big E. The rivalry between the two groups was intense, with The Bloodline eventually emerging victorious.

#### Induction of Sami Zayn and Solo Sikoa (2022–2023)

In 2022, The Bloodline expanded its membership, inducting Sami Zayn and Solo Sikoa. Zayn, a longtime friend of The Usos, had recently turned heel, while Sikoa, a cousin of Roman Reigns, was making his WWE debut. The additions strengthened the group, which continued to dominate WWE.

#### Bloodline Civil War (2023)

However, tensions within The Bloodline began to rise, eventually leading to a civil war within the group. The conflict, sparked by disagreements between Roman Reigns and Sami Zayn, saw the group splinter into two factions. The Usos and Solo Sikoa remained loyal to Roman Reigns, while Sami Zayn was joined by Kevin Owens and other allies.

#### Addition of The Rock and feud with Cody Rhodes (2023–2024)

In a shocking turn of events, The Rock, a WWE legend and cousin of Roman Reigns, joined The Bloodline. The group, now stronger than ever, set its sights on Cody Rhodes, a longtime rival of Roman Reigns. The feud between the two was intense, with The Bloodline eventually emerging victorious.

### Solo Sikoa's leadership (2024–present)

#### Additions of The Tongans and Jacob Fatu (2024)

In 2024, Solo Sikoa took over as the leader of The Bloodline, following Roman Reigns' departure from the group. The new leader quickly expanded the group's membership, inducting The Tongans, a tag team consisting of Tama Tonga and Tanga Loa, and Jacob Fatu, a cousin of Roman Reigns.

#### Bloodline Civil War II (2024–present)

However, the group's newfound stability was short-lived, as tensions within The Bloodline began to rise once again. The conflict, sparked by disagreements between Solo Sikoa and The Usos, saw the group splinter into two factions. The Tongans and Jacob Fatu remained loyal to Solo Sikoa, while The Usos were joined by other allies.

Members
-------

### Current

* Solo Sikoa (leader)
* The Tongans (Tama Tonga and Tanga Loa)
* Jacob Fatu

### Former

* Roman Reigns (founder and former leader)
* The Usos (Jimmy and Jey Uso)

Timeline
--------

* 2013: The Usos begin their feud with The Shield.

2023 Durand Cup

The 2023 Durand Cup is the 132nd edition of the Durand Cup, India's oldest association football tournament. The tournament is scheduled to take place from August 3 to September 3, 2023, in multiple venues across India.

# Teams

A total of 24 teams are participating in the 2023 Durand Cup, including 5 teams from the Indian Super League (ISL), 5 teams from the I-League, 6 teams from the I-League 2nd Division, 4 teams from the Indian Armed Forces, and 4 teams from the Indian Railways.

article:
History of the Telephone in the United States

The history of the telephone in the United States is a story of innovation, expansion, and transformation. From its early beginnings in the late 19th century to the present day, the telephone has played a significant role in shaping American society, culture, and economy. This article explores the major developments in the history of the telephone in the United States, from the early days of AT&T and the Bell System to the rise of cellphones and smartphones.

# AT&T and the Bell System

The history of the telephone in the United States is closely tied to the story of AT&T and the Bell System. The Bell System was a network of telephone companies that dominated the industry for much of the 20th century.

## American Bell Telephone Company (1881–1899)

The American Bell Telephone Company was founded in 1881 by Alexander Graham Bell, the inventor of the telephone. The company's initial focus was on developing and marketing the telephone, which was initially met with skepticism by the public. However, the company's fortunes changed with the introduction of the first telephone exchange in Boston in 1877, which allowed multiple telephones to be connected to a central switchboard.

## AT&T (1899–1982)

In 1899, American Bell Telephone Company was renamed AT&T (American Telephone and Telegraph Company). Under the leadership of Theodore Vail, AT&T expanded rapidly, acquiring several smaller telephone companies and establishing a network of long-distance lines. The company's growth was fueled by the increasing demand for telephone services, particularly in urban areas.

## Research priority

AT&T was committed to research and development, establishing the famous Bell Labs in 1925. Bell Labs was responsible for many significant innovations, including the development of the transistor, the laser, and the first commercial touch-tone phone.

## Targeting an audience

AT&T targeted different audiences with its services, including urban and rural communities.

### Urban public telephones

In urban areas, AT&T installed public telephones, which became a common sight on street corners and in public spaces. Public telephones were seen as a convenient and affordable way for people to make phone calls, particularly for those who did not have access to a home phone.

### Rural telephone service

In rural areas, AT&T faced significant challenges in providing telephone services. The company developed specialized equipment and techniques to overcome the difficulties of serving rural communities, including the use of party lines, which allowed multiple households to share the same telephone line.

## Breakup of AT&T in 1982

In 1982, AT&T was broken up into seven regional Bell operating companies, known as the Baby Bells, as a result of antitrust litigation. The breakup marked the end of AT&T's dominance of the telephone industry and paved the way for increased competition and innovation.

# Cellphones and smartphones

The development of cellphones and smartphones revolutionized the telephone industry in the latter half of the 20th century.

The first mobile phone call was made in 1973 by Martin Cooper, an engineer at Motorola. The first commercial cellphones were released in the 1980s, but they were expensive and had limited functionality.

The introduction of smartphones in the late 1990s and early 2000s marked a significant turning point in the history of the telephone. Smartphones combined the functionality of a computer with the portability of a cellphone, enabling users to access the internet, send emails, and use apps on the go.

# Personnel

The history of the telephone in the United States is also the story of the people who worked in the industry.

## Switchboard and operators

In the early days of the telephone, switchboard operators played a crucial role in connecting calls. Operators were responsible for answering calls, connecting lines, and providing directory assistance.

## Labor force: bias for and against women

The telephone industry was one of the first to employ large numbers of women. However, women faced significant challenges and biases in the workplace, including lower pay and limited opportunities for advancement.

### Strikes

In the early 20th century, telephone operators went on strike several times to protest working conditions and demand better pay and benefits.

## Hawthorne studies

In the 1920s and 1930s, the Hawthorne studies were conducted to examine the effects of working conditions on employee productivity. The studies, which were conducted at Western Electric's Hawthorne plant in Illinois, found that employees were more productive when they were given attention and support, regardless of the working conditions.

## Employee benefits

The telephone industry was a leader in providing employee benefits, including health insurance, pensions, and paid time off. These benefits helped to attract and retain employees, particularly in the competitive post-war era.

# Users

The history of the telephone in the United States is also the story of the people who used the technology.

## Business

The telephone was initially seen as a business tool, particularly in urban areas. Businesses used the telephone to communicate with customers, suppliers, and partners.

## Housewives

In the mid-20th century, the telephone became a popular tool for housewives, who used it to connect with friends and family, as well as to manage household tasks.

## Gender and culture roles

The telephone played a significant role in shaping gender and culture roles, particularly in the mid-20th century. The telephone was seen as a feminine technology, and women were expected to be the primary users.

## Telemarketing

The development of telemarketing in the mid-20th century marked a significant shift in the way businesses used the telephone. Telemarketing allowed businesses to reach large numbers of customers directly, but it also raised concerns about privacy and annoyance.

## 9-1-1

The introduction of the 9-1-1 emergency number in the 1960s marked a significant improvement in emergency services. 9-1-1 allowed callers to quickly and easily reach emergency services, such as police, fire, and ambulance.

## Harassing calls

The telephone also raised concerns about harassing calls, particularly in the mid-20th century. Harassing calls, including obscene calls and prank calls, were seen as a significant problem.

## Literary fears

The telephone also raised literary fears, particularly in the mid-20th century. Authors such as Ray Bradbury and Kurt Vonnegut wrote about the dangers of the telephone, including its potential to isolate individuals and destroy traditional forms of communication.

# References

* Brooks, John (1976). Telephone: The First Hundred Years. Harper & Row.
* Fischer, Claude S. (1992). America Calling: A Social History of the Telephone to 1940. University of California Press.
* Lipartito, Kenneth (1994). The Bell System and Regional Business: The Telephone in the South, 1877-1920. Johns Hopkins University Press.

# Further reading

## Social and cultural studies
