2022 National League Division Series

The 2022 National League Division Series (NLDS) were two best-of-five game series in Major League Baseball (MLB) that determined the participants in the 2022 National League Championship Series (NLCS). The three division winners in the National League (NL) seeded one through three based on their win-loss records, and the winners of the two wild card spots seeded four and five. The team with the better record in each matchup hosted Games 1, 2, and 5 (if necessary), while the other team hosted Games 3 and 4 (if necessary).

# Background

The 2022 NLDS were the first postseason games for the Philadelphia Phillies since 2011 and the first for the San Diego Padres since 2006. The Atlanta Braves were looking to repeat as National League champions, while the Los Angeles Dodgers were seeking their fifth NLCS appearance in six years.

# Matchups

## Los Angeles Dodgers vs. San Diego Padres

The Los Angeles Dodgers, winners of the National League West division, were seeded one and faced the San Diego Padres, the winners of the National League wild card series against the New York Mets. The Dodgers were led by manager Dave Roberts, while the Padres were managed by Bob Melvin.

## Atlanta Braves vs. Philadelphia Phillies

The Atlanta Braves, winners of the National League East division, were seeded two and faced the Philadelphia Phillies, the winners of the National League wild card series against the St. Louis Cardinals. The Braves were led by manager Brian Snitker, while the Phillies were managed by Rob Thomson.

# Los Angeles vs. San Diego

The Dodgers and Padres faced off in the NLDS for the first time since 1996.

## Game 1

Game 1 was played at Dodger Stadium in Los Angeles, California on October 11. The Dodgers took an early lead on a two-run home run by Will Smith in the first inning. The Padres tied the game in the third inning on a two-run single by Manny Machado. The game remained tied until the eighth inning, when the Dodgers took the lead on a sacrifice fly by Justin Turner. The Dodgers added an insurance run in the ninth inning on a solo home run by Chris Taylor. The Dodgers won the game 5-3.

## Game 2

Game 2 was played at Dodger Stadium on October 12. The Padres took an early lead on a solo home run by Juan Soto in the first inning. The Dodgers tied the game in the third inning on a solo home run by Freddie Freeman. The game remained tied until the fifth inning, when the Padres took the lead on a two-run single by Brandon Drury. The Padres added an insurance run in the ninth inning on a solo home run by Trent Grisham. The Padres won the game 5-3.

## Game 3

Game 3 was played at Petco Park in San Diego, California on October 14. The Padres took an early lead on a solo home run by Manny Machado in the first inning. The Dodgers tied the game in the third inning on a solo home run by Max Muncy. The game remained tied until the seventh inning, when the Padres took the lead on a two-run single by Trent Grisham. The Padres added an insurance run in the eighth inning on a solo home run by Juan Soto. The Padres won the game 5-3.

## Game 4

Game 4 was played at Petco Park on October 15. The Dodgers took an early lead on a two-run home run by Will Smith in the first inning. The Padres tied the game in the third inning on a two-run single by Manny Machado. The game remained tied until the seventh inning, when the Dodgers took the lead on a solo home run by Chris Taylor. The Dodgers added an insurance run in the ninth inning on a solo home run by Justin Turner. The Dodgers won the game 5-3.

The Braves and Phillies faced off in the NLDS for the first time since 1993.

Game 1 was played at Truist Park in Atlanta, Georgia on October 11. The Braves took an early lead on a two-run home run by Austin Riley in the first inning. The Phillies tied the game in the third inning on a two-run single by Bryce Harper. The game remained tied until the sixth inning, when the Braves took the lead on a solo home run by Matt Olson. The Braves added an insurance run in the eighth inning on a solo home run by Travis d'Arnaud. The Braves won the game 4-2.

The Braves tied the game in the third inning on a solo home run by Ronald Acuña Jr. The game remained tied until the seventh inning, when the Phillies took the lead on a two-run single by Bryce Harper. The Phillies added an insurance run in the ninth inning on a solo home run by Rhys Hoskins. The Phillies won the game 4-2.

article:
Sound of Freedom (film)

Sound of Freedom is a 2023 American drama film written and directed by Alejandro Monteverde. The film is based on the true story of Tim Ballard, a former CIA operative who founded Operation Underground Railroad (O.U.R.), an organization dedicated to rescuing victims of human trafficking.

# Plot

The film follows the story of Tim Ballard (played by Jim Caviezel), a former CIA operative who becomes disillusioned with the agency's lack of action against human traffickers. Ballard leaves the CIA and founds Operation Underground Railroad, a non-profit organization dedicated to rescuing victims of human trafficking. The film depicts Ballard's early struggles to get the organization off the ground, as well as his first successful rescue mission in Colombia. As the organization grows, Ballard and his team face numerous challenges and obstacles, including corrupt government officials and violent traffickers. Despite these challenges, Ballard remains committed to his mission and continues to work tirelessly to free victims of human trafficking.

# Cast

* Jim Caviezel as Tim Ballard
* Mira Sorvino as Katherine Ballard
* Bill Camp as Tom Phillips
* José Zúñiga as Javier
* Gerardo Taracena as Roberto
* Eduardo Verástegui as Paul

# Production

## Development

The film was in development for several years, with Alejandro Monteverde working closely with Tim Ballard to develop the script. Monteverde was drawn to the project because of his own experiences as an immigrant and his desire to highlight the issue of human trafficking. The film was produced by Monteverde's production company, Angel Studios, in association with O.U.R. Films.

## Filming

Principal photography took place in Mexico and the Dominican Republic, with additional filming in the United States. The film's cinematographer, Andrés Sánchez, used a mix of handheld camera work and static shots to create a sense of realism and intimacy. The film's score was composed by Javier Navarrete, who incorporated traditional Latin American music into the soundtrack.

## Distribution

The film was distributed by Angel Studios and O.U.R. Films, with a limited release in the United States in July 2023. The film was also made available on streaming platforms, including Amazon Prime Video and YouTube.

## Accuracy

The film is based on the true story of Tim Ballard and Operation Underground Railroad, but some creative liberties were taken to enhance the storytelling and characters. Ballard has stated that the film is "about 90% accurate," with some events and characters being composites or fictionalized for dramatic effect.

# Connections to QAnon conspiracy theories

The film has been linked to QAnon conspiracy theories, with some promoters and fans of the film using QAnon hashtags and slogans on social media. However, the film's director and producers have denied any connection to QAnon or its ideology. Tim Ballard has also stated that he is not a supporter of QAnon and that the film is not meant to promote any conspiracy theories.

# Pay-it-forward scheme

The film's producers launched a pay-it-forward scheme, encouraging viewers to donate to O.U.R. in exchange for tickets to the film. The scheme was designed to raise awareness and funds for O.U.R. and its mission to combat human trafficking.

================

Leland Sklar is a renowned American bassist and session musician, best known for his work as a member of the Los Angeles-based session group, The Section. With a career spanning over five decades, Sklar has played on numerous iconic recordings, collaborated with a wide range of artists, and has become one of the most respected and sought-after bassists in the music industry.

Early Life
-----------

Leland Sklar was born on May 26, 1947, in Milwaukee, Wisconsin. He began playing music at a young age, starting with the accordion before switching to the bass guitar in his teenage years. Sklar's early influences were rooted in rock and roll, jazz, and classical music, which would later shape his unique playing style. After high school, he attended the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, where he studied music and began to develop his skills as a bassist.

Career
-------

Sklar's professional career began in the late 1960s, playing in various local bands and working as a session musician in the Milwaukee area. In the early 1970s, he relocated to Los Angeles, where he became a member of The Section, a group of session musicians that included drummer Russ Kunkel, guitarist Danny Kortchmar, and keyboardist Craig Doerge. The Section quickly gained a reputation as one of the top session groups in the city, working with a wide range of artists, including James Taylor, Carole King, and Jackson Browne.

Throughout the 1970s and 1980s, Sklar played on numerous iconic recordings, including James Taylor's "Sweet Baby James," Carole King's "Tapestry," and Jackson Browne's "Running on Empty." He also worked with artists such as Linda Ronstadt, Stevie Nicks, and Don Henley, among many others. Sklar's versatility and ability to adapt to different styles and genres made him a sought-after bassist, and he quickly became one of the most in-demand session musicians in Los Angeles.

article:
2022 AFC Futsal Asian Cup

The 2022 AFC Futsal Asian Cup was the 16th edition of the AFC Futsal Asian Cup, the premier international futsal tournament of Asia organized by the Asian Football Confederation (AFC). The tournament was held in Kuwait from September 8 to 17, 2022.

# Qualification

The qualification process for the 2022 AFC Futsal Asian Cup took place from April 2022. A total of 17 teams competed in the qualification tournament, with the top teams from each group advancing to the final tournament.

## Qualified Teams

A total of 16 teams qualified for the final tournament. The qualified teams were:

*  Afghanistan
*  Bahrain
*  China
*  Chinese Taipei
*  Hong Kong
*  India
*  Indonesia
*  Iran
*  Iraq
*  Japan
*  Kuwait (hosts)
*  Lebanon
*  Mongolia
*  Saudi Arabia
*  South Korea
*  Thailand

# Venues

The tournament was held in two venues in Kuwait:

* Kuwait Sports Club Stadium, Kuwait City
* Sheikh Saad Al-Abdullah Sports Hall, Hawalli

# Draw

The draw for the group stage took place on August 25, 2022, in Kuwait City. The 16 teams were drawn into four groups of four teams each. The teams were seeded based on their performance in the previous edition of the tournament.

# Squads

Each team was allowed to register a squad of 14 players. The squads were announced by the AFC on September 5, 2022.

# Group Stage

The group stage took place from September 8 to 12, 2022. The teams played each other in a round-robin format, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage.

Endorsements in the July–September 2022 Conservative Party leadership election

The July–September 2022 Conservative Party leadership election was triggered by the resignation of Prime Minister Boris Johnson as leader of the Conservative Party. The election was contested by eight candidates, with the winner becoming the new leader of the Conservative Party and Prime Minister of the United Kingdom. This article lists the endorsements received by each of the candidates during the election.

article:
Dumas Malone
================

Dumas Malone was a renowned American historian and author, best known for his comprehensive six-volume biography of Thomas Jefferson, "Jefferson and His Time". Malone's work on Jefferson is widely regarded as the definitive study of the third President of the United States, and his scholarship has had a lasting impact on the field of American history.

Early Life and Education
------------------------

### Upbringing

Dumas Malone was born on January 10, 1892, in Coldwater, Mississippi, to parents who were both educators. His father, John Edward Malone, was a school principal, and his mother, Lizzie Dumas Malone, was a teacher. Malone's early life was marked by a strong emphasis on education, which would shape his future academic pursuits. He grew up in a family that valued learning and encouraged his curiosity about the world.

### Ministry and Yale

Malone's initial career aspiration was to become a minister. He attended Mississippi College, a Baptist institution, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in 1911. However, he soon became disillusioned with the ministry and turned his attention to academia. Malone went on to earn a Master of Arts degree from Yale University in 1916, where he began to develop his interests in history and biography.

Career
--------

### Virginia and the DAB

In 1916, Malone began his academic career as a professor of history at the University of Virginia. During his time in Charlottesville, he became involved with the Dictionary of American Biography (DAB), a project that aimed to compile comprehensive biographies of notable Americans. Malone's work on the DAB would eventually lead him to Thomas Jefferson, a figure who would dominate his scholarly pursuits for the remainder of his life.

### Harvard University Press

In 1923, Malone became the editor of the Harvard University Press, a position that allowed him to shape the press's publication agenda and pursue his own research interests. During his tenure at Harvard, Malone oversaw the publication of numerous influential works of history and established himself as a respected scholar in his own right.

### Return to Virginia

In 1929, Malone returned to the University of Virginia, where he would remain for the next three decades. He continued to teach and conduct research, gradually building a reputation as a leading authority on Thomas Jefferson. Malone's work on Jefferson would eventually culminate in the publication of his six-volume biography, "Jefferson and His Time".

Legacy and Honors
-----------------

Dumas Malone's scholarship has had a lasting impact on the field of American history. His biography of Thomas Jefferson is widely regarded as the definitive study of the third President, and his work has influenced generations of historians. Malone received numerous awards and honors for his scholarship, including the Pulitzer Prize for History in 1975.

Personal Life and Death
-----------------------

Malone married Elizabeth Green in 1916, and the couple had two children together. He was known for his warm and generous personality, and his love of teaching and mentoring. Malone died on December 19, 1986, at the age of 94, leaving behind a legacy of distinguished scholarship and a profound impact on our understanding of American history.

Selected Publications
---------------------

### Jefferson and His Time

Malone's magnum opus, "Jefferson and His Time", is a six-volume biography that spans Jefferson's life from his birth in 1743 to his death in 1826. The work is characterized by its meticulous research, engaging prose, and nuanced understanding of Jefferson's complex personality. The volumes are:

1. "Jefferson the Virginian" (1948)
2. "Jefferson and the Rights of Man" (1951)
3. "Jefferson and the Ordeal of Liberty" (1962)
4. "Jefferson the President: First Term, 1801-1805" (1970)
5. "Jefferson the President: Second Term, 1805-1809" (1974)
6. "The Sage of Monticello" (1981)

Footnotes
----------

This article is based on a variety of scholarly sources, including books and journal articles. While Malone's work on Jefferson is widely regarded as definitive, other historians have offered alternative perspectives and interpretations of the third President's life and legacy.

References
----------

### Scholarly Sources

#### Books

* Malone, Dumas. "Jefferson and His Time". 6 vols. Boston: Little, Brown and Company, 1948-1981.
* Peterson, Merrill D. "The Jefferson Image in the American Mind". New York: Oxford University Press, 1960.
* Ellis, Joseph J. "American Sphinx: The Character of Thomas Jefferson". New York: Alfred A. Knopf, 1997.

#### Journals

* Malone, Dumas. "The Jefferson Papers of the University of Virginia". William and Mary Quarterly, 3rd ser., 10 (1953): 567-584.
* Peterson, Merrill D. "Thomas Jefferson and the Historians". Journal of American History, 60 (1973): 335-346.

Further Reading
----------------

* Jefferson, Thomas. "The Papers of Thomas Jefferson". Edited by Julian P. Boyd. 32 vols. Princeton: Princeton University Press, 1950-1981.
* Randall, Willard Sterne. "Thomas Jefferson: A Life". New York: Henry Holt and Company, 1993.

External Links
---------------

* University of Virginia: Dumas Malone Papers
* Harvard University Press: Dumas Malone
* Thomas Jefferson Foundation: Jefferson and His Time

2022 Indonesia Open

The 2022 Indonesia Open was a badminton tournament which took place at the Istora Gelora Bung Karno in Jakarta, Indonesia, from 14 to 19 June 2022. It had a total purse of $1,200,000.

Tournament

Venue

The 2022 Indonesia Open was held at the Istora Gelora Bung Karno in Jakarta, Indonesia. This venue has hosted numerous international badminton tournaments, including the Indonesia Open, and has a seating capacity of over 7,000 spectators.

Point distribution

The 2022 Indonesia Open was a BWF World Tour Super 1000 tournament, which meant that it awarded a significant number of ranking points to the participants. The point distribution for this tournament was as follows:

* Winner: 12,000 points
* Runner-up: 10,200 points
* Semi-finalist: 8,400 points
* Quarter-finalist: 6,600 points
* Round of 16: 4,800 points
* Round of 32: 3,000 points
* Qualifier: 1,200 points

Prize money

The total prize money for the 2022 Indonesia Open was $1,200,000, which was one of the highest purses on the BWF World Tour. The prize money was distributed as follows:

* Winner: $90,000
* Runner-up: $43,000
* Semi-finalist: $20,000
* Quarter-finalist: $11,000
* Round of 16: $6,000
* Round of 32: $3,500
* Qualifier: $2,000

Men's singles

Seeds

The top 8 seeds in the men's singles event were:

1. Kento Momota (Japan)
2. Viktor Axelson (Denmark)
3. Anders Antonsen (Denmark)
4. Chou Tien-chen (Taiwan)
5. Anthony Sinisuka Ginting (Indonesia)
6. Jonatan Christie (Indonesia)
7. Lee Zii Jia (Malaysia)
8. Rasmus Gemke (Denmark)

Finals

The final match of the men's singles event was played between Viktor Axelson and Chou Tien-chen. Axelson won the match in straight games, 21-10, 21-12.

Top half

Section 1

The top section of the draw featured the top seed Kento Momota, who faced off against the qualifier Sittikom Thammasin in the first round. Momota won the match in straight games, 21-12, 21-15. In the second round, Momota faced off against the Danish player Hans-Kristian Solberg Vittinghus, who he defeated in three games, 21-13, 19-21, 21-14.

Section 2

The second section of the draw featured the 4th seed Chou Tien-chen, who faced off against the Indonesian player Tommy Sugiarto in the first round. Chou won the match in straight games, 21-18, 21-15. In the second round, Chou faced off against the Malaysian player Daren Liew, who he defeated in three games, 21-17, 14-21, 21-14.

Bottom half

Operation London Bridge is a codename for the plan of action to be taken in the event of the death of Charles, Prince of Wales. The operation is designed to ensure a smooth transition of power and to facilitate the accession of Prince William, Duke of Cambridge, to the throne. The plan is a comprehensive and detailed document that outlines the steps to be taken by government officials, the royal family, and other stakeholders in the event of the prince's death.

# Background

The death of a senior member of the royal family is a significant event that requires careful planning and execution. The British government and the royal family have a long history of preparing for such events, and Operation London Bridge is the latest iteration of this planning. The operation is designed to minimize disruption and to ensure that the transition of power is as smooth as possible.

Operation London Bridge is a comprehensive plan that outlines the steps to be taken in the event of the death of Charles, Prince of Wales. The plan is divided into several phases, each of which is designed to address a specific aspect of the transition.
